customData.content: 62-year-old woman with incidentally identified solitary pulmonary nodule in the lateral segment of the right middle lobe (RML) found on CT of the abdomen and pelvis for evaluation of epigastric abdominal pain. Medical history significant for hypertension. Patient reported bronchitis-like symptoms characterised by cough, sputum production, low-grade fever and malaise several months ago, which resolved over a few weeks.

imaging.body_part: Lateral segment of the right middle lobe

HPI.summary: Patient reported bronchitis-like symptoms characterised by cough, sputum production, low-grade fever and malaise several months ago, which resolved over a few weeks.

customData.content: Patient denies systemic or respiratory symptoms. Never smoker, works as an ophthalmology nurse practitioner. No history of tuberculosis (TB) or known exposure to patients with TB. Never travelled outside the USA but lived in a Histoplasma endemic rural midwestern state.

social_history.description: works as an ophthalmology nurse practitioner

customData.content: Physical examination normal. CT scan of the chest demonstrated a mildly irregular, non-calcified 1.4 x 1.0 cm subpleural pulmonary nodule in the right middle lobe (RML). No hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy. No pets at home.

imaging.finding: mildly irregular, non-calcified 1.4 x 1.0 cm subpleural pulmonary nodule
imaging.impression: Pulmonary nodule in the right middle lobe (RML). No hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.

customData.content: PET scan revealed a hypermetabolic RML lung nodule with a standard uptake value of 3.6. No hypermetabolic intrathoracic lymph nodes or evidence of extrathoracic disease. Axial CT of the chest revealed a mildly irregular subpleural pulmonary nodule in the lateral segment of the right middle lobe with mild pleural thickening adjacent to the lesion.

imaging.finding: hypermetabolic RML lung nodule with a standard uptake value of 3.6
imaging.impression: No hypermetabolic intrathoracic lymph nodes or evidence of extrathoracic disease.

imaging.finding: mildly irregular subpleural pulmonary nodule in the lateral segment of the right middle lobe with mild pleural thickening adjacent to the lesion

customData.content: CT guided core needle biopsy of the RML nodule. Histopathology revealed a parasite with a thick multi-layered cuticular layer measuring 85 µm in cross-sectional diameter, lodged in a small pulmonary artery branch, with lymphocytic infiltration of the vessel and disruption of the endothelial layer. Histopathology showed perivascular granulomatous inflammation. Parasite with thick cuticular layer, suspected to be Dirofilaria immitis. Histopathology revealed parasitic morphologies consistent with Dirofilaria immitis, lymphocytic infiltrate of the disrupted vascular endothelium, areas of necrosis surrounding the lesion, and perivascular granulomatous inflammation.

procedures.name: Core needle biopsy
procedures.outcome: Parasite with thick cuticular layer, suspected to be Dirofilaria immitis

labs.value: Parasite with thick cuticular layer, suspected to be Dirofilaria immitis

customData.content: Filaria IgG4 antibody measured by ELISA showed a high antibody level but still within equivocal range (IgG4 antibody 2.7, negative test <1.5, positive test >3).

Patient diagnosed with human pulmonary dirofilariasis (HPD) and managed conservatively. Histopathological analysis of the core needle biopsy of the pulmonary nodule showed a parasite with thick multi-layered cuticle lodged in the small pulmonary artery branch. The parasite measured 85 µm in cross-sectional diameter and demonstrated advanced stages of decomposition. Degenerating muscular ridges were also seen.

procedures.name: Core needle biopsy
procedures.outcome: Histopathological analysis showed a parasite with thick multi-layered cuticle lodged in the small pulmonary artery branch. The parasite measured 85 µm in cross-sectional diameter and demonstrated advanced stages of decomposition. Degenerating muscular ridges were also seen.

customData.content: Follow-up CT chest approximately 1 year after diagnosis revealed a reduction in the size (1.1 x 0.9 cm) and solidity of the RML lesion.

data.content: Transition from initial presentation to further history taking, including smoking, TB exposure, and travel history.
Transition from history taking to physical examination and CT scan results, revealing a pulmonary nodule in the RML.
Transition from CT scan to PET scan, revealing a hypermetabolic RML lung nodule.
Transition from imaging to CT-guided core needle biopsy of the RML nodule, revealing a parasite consistent with Dirofilaria immitis.
Transition from histopathology to Filaria IgG4 antibody testing, showing equivocal results.
Transition from equivocal antibody results to diagnosis of human pulmonary dirofilariasis (HPD) and conservative management. Further histopathological analysis is mentioned.
Transition from diagnosis and management to follow-up CT chest approximately 1 year later, revealing a reduction in the size and solidity of the RML lesion.
